Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Norain> How can 3 computer on 1 LAN

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Norain> Mine one wallet??

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Norain> Copy wallet ??

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> @Norain You can copy a wallet between the computers, but be aware that after a time they may generate new addresses that aren't common between them. The safest way to do it, if you're using the CLI is to use the pubkey parameter.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <englal> On linux, for instance, you would start verusd using:
./verusd -pubkey=XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> That will cause all blocks mined to use only the address for that public key.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <englal> Agama should have an option to copy the public key for an address. In the CLI you can do the following:
./verus getaddressesbyaccount ""              - to list your addresses
or
./verus getnewaddres                                      - to get a new address instead
then
./verus validateaddress XXXXXXXXXXXXX         - putting in the address you want the public key for
the result of that command is the public key for that address.

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> @Mike1900  The first time you run either Agama or the CLI it will create a file called wallet.dat. The location of this file differs based on your operating system. On linux this will be in ~/.komodo/VRSC

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> @Mike1900 When you receive or mine coins they will go to addresses that are recorded in the wallet file.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> I have been mining on 7 machines and using the PRIV KEYs to import into one main wallet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> @jimboscott I think you should be fine. I'm of the mind that it's a good idea to NEVER delete a wallet.dat file unless you're positive it is empty and hasn't made its way onto any other machines, or been mined to using pubkey, etc.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> If you hang onto that file you know that data will be secure.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> I will back them up, but not have the 'outside' wallets mining to a wallet that I have already exported everything from.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Gets messy that way.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> And on import, just make sure the addresses show up, reindex if needed, and I would call their presence in the UI, be it Agama or CLI, sufficient evidence that it is safe to use that wallet and expect those addresses to be used like any others in the wallet.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> Probably the most fundamental thing to know is that what you have in your wallet is not some piece of data that is the coins, it is the cryptographic keys that allow you to spend the coins. The coins are basically a collection of balances on the blockchain - a public ledger. Your wallet allows the software to scan the blockchain and figure out which of those balances are yours, and allows you to create a transaction that spends them, using that key, known as the private key.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> Your wallet.dat file, or any private keys you export from it should be treated like cash. Anyone that ever gets access to them could potentially spend your coins. So the security of the technology is only as secure as you are able to keep that file.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> SOmeone needs to make a wallet that lets you name your wallet.dat file something like 'catsatplay.jpg'

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> Likewise, if you lose your wallet, either because the hard drive dies, you delete it, it becomes corrupted, etc., the coins are lost to you. They still exist on that ledger, but you no longer have the key that allows you to spend them.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Mike1900> how do we backup the wallet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Mike1900> just any place safe like usb key ?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> Excellent question. Shut down the software, whether agama or the CLI. Once it has finished shutting down, you can just copy that wallet.dat file to somewhere safe, and after the copy is complete (it's not typically a large file) you can restart the software.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Mike1900> ok

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> You can also export the wallet in a text format that gives you more direct access to the private keys, etc., which is useful for combining wallets, etc., or as an extra safety measure on a wallet backup.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> Always make sure your wallets don't have a chance to sync to any cloud storage or anything like that which could expose them to any third parties. A thumb drive is a great way to back wallets up.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> No, it will pick up where it left off.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> Also remember that new data goes into your wallet file after certain types of activity, such as creating new addresses, after very much mining, etc., so it should be backed up regularly, especially after you receive any large funds, etc.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> Right now you're syncing the blockchain, downloading a local copy from peers and scanning it to both verify it's integrity and look for transactions that appear in your wallet. I don't know for sure, but I wouldn't expect it to be writing to the wallet during the sync.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> And you won't be able to mine until you have finished syncing the chain.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> Mining is basically like trying to win a lottery that happens every two minutes, and the number of tickets you have is proportional to the amount of computing power you can put into it. Sometimes you'll go days, maybe weeks without getting anything, sometimes you get lucky and get a bunch all at once sometime. It is completely random, but again, in proportion to your hash power.
